nodes.bodyText: Please split this method into two.
I think there is a problem with starting the stage in a test within SpriteActivity? (flaky) @84n4n4 Is that true?
As discussed with Thomas, please refactor it to StageActivity.
Please check if this brick is really necessary.
it is necessary to let a sound play for a short time so that it is possible to check that it did not start from the beginning when continuing a scene.

Please rename this function.
Maybe it is useful to map sounds to positions.
You may not want to add sounds that are not playing.
Please refactor this as discussed.

This line seems not right. Could you please check why this is public? (I know you didn't write this line ^^)
(if it's only used in tests => visible for testing and hopefully, there is no occurrence in the code)
Or if it's in the tests => mock. Thank you!

This seems a bit too complicated for this task. Instead of two separate lists of sound files and media Players. You could map one sound file to one MediaPlayer from the beginning (in play sound).
For further processing see https://mkyong.com/java8/java-8-filter-a-map-examples/
map<String, MediaPlayer> => filter => map => collect = map<string, Integer>

Good Points, thanks!
Unfortunatly using stream is only possible starting with API 24 and as per my IDE is the current min 21.
Ok, then its probably fine as it is. You can decide if you want to refactor this or leave it like that.
The name is ok, but it is the only difference to playSound. Please remove it and/or rename Play Sound)
Nice!
Nice fix!
In runProject the whole Project is run, both scripts get executed - the parameter is only used to wait until this Script is fully evaluated.
Thank you for explaining!

PLEASE EXPLAIN: Have you checked this test in test-first style, i.e., before you implemented the fix? And what is the unit for the current position here? Can't this asset be true even if the sound was restarted, because of timing issues? Please clarify and confirm.

I did start my tests without my fix and all of them failed.
The current position is the time played in milliseconds.
Yes, I think timing issues are a potential problem here, but I did not find a better way to check this.

Thanks! How about, after starting the sound in the first scene, to wait for 0.1 second while still in the first scene using a "wait 0.1 seconds" brick, and then when returning back from the second scene immediately checking that the current position is > 100? Would that work?

Oh I forgot to mention that, I already have a "wait 0.5 seconds" brick and after some testing it seems that I have to wait at least 0.3 seconds for the sound to start.
This seems to be very inconsistent and unfortunately I don't think a more precise check is possible.
Well, shouldn't it then be >200? You could compare to > 150 instead of > 0, right?
I just want to make these tests future proof (Moore's law...)

After running the test three times the position of the Sound when transitioning back were: 227, 82, 141 ms
It really varies a lot.
At least > 50?
Thanks!
